title: Work and Employment
summary: Essential vocabulary to talk about jobs and employment, including verbs, nouns, and phrases related to working conditions, job types, and employment status.

sections.heading: Verbs Related to Work
sections.content: This section covers common verbs and phrases used when talking about employment and work situations.

examples.example: Sam earns $30,000 a year in his job as a chef.

examples.definition: To work more hours than are stated in your contract.
examples.example: We're very busy at work right now, so I'm doing a lot of overtime.

examples.definition: To show interest in a position by sending your CV and other documents.
examples.example: When I heard about the vacancy, I applied for the job immediately.
Tom resigned from his job because he'd decided to take a year off and go travelling.

examples.definition: To stop working altogether, usually because of old age.
examples.example: I plan to retire as soon as I turn 65.

examples.definition: To be given a position with more responsibility.
examples.example: Nick was promoted to floor manager just months after joining the company.

examples.definition: To be dismissed from a job, usually because of poor performance.
examples.example: James was sacked from his job at the supermarket after he was caught stealing money.

examples.definition: To have authority or control over somebody or something.
examples.example: As manager of a busy caf√©, Sara is in charge of 15 members of staff.

sections.heading: Nouns and Adjectives Related to Work
sections.content: This section covers common nouns and adjectives used to describe job types and employment situations.

examples.definition: A job where a person works a standard number of hours each week.
examples.example: As soon as he finished school, Tim got a full-time job in a bank.

examples.definition: A job with fewer hours than a full-time position.
examples.example: When I was a student, I had a part-time waitressing job.

examples.definition: To work during various scheduled periods of the day or night.
examples.example: When I was a nurse, I worked a lot of night shifts.

examples.definition: A job that is not permanent.
examples.example: Eve has a temporary job in a school, covering for a teacher who is on maternity leave.

examples.definition: Working for yourself rather than for a company.
examples.example: Alice is a self-employed writer and works from home.

examples.definition: Without a job and looking for work.
examples.example: Bob has been unemployed since he lost his job last year.

examples.definition: The place where you go to do your job.
examples.example: Our office is a friendly workplace; we all get on really well.

examples.definition: Certificates or degrees that qualify you for a job.
examples.example: Ian was not given the job because he didn't have the right qualifications.

sections.heading: Work vs Job
sections.content: This section explains the difference between these commonly confused terms.

examples.definition: A countable noun referring to a profession or occupation.
examples.example: He's had many different jobs. This is a difficult job.

examples.definition: An uncountable noun referring to the activity of doing a job.
examples.example: I have a lot of work to do. What time do you finish work?

examples.definition: Can also mean the place where people do their job.
examples.example: How do you go to work? I have lunch at work.
